Limit of Blank (LOB).  The highest apparent analyte concentration expected to be found when a replicate of a sample containing no analyte are tested. Concentration units must be specified in the "Units" column! For qualitative tests.
Notes: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Label: Limit of Detection (LOD). The minimum amount or concentration of analyte that can be reliably distinguished from zero. Concentration units must be specified in the "Units" column! For qualitative tests.
Notes: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Label: Signal to noise ratio used to define the limit of detection in standard deviations.
Description of how limit of detection was determined.
Notes: Example: A dilution series of heat inactivated SARS-CoV-2 virus stock (USA-WA1/2020) was prepared in natural clinical matrix (pooled nasopharyngeal swab samples eluted in VTM). Five (5) replicates were tested per dilution. The testing was performed as per the recommended instructions for use, with the virus in clinical matrix applied directly onto the Swab until the saturation of the flocked tip. The estimated LoD concentration for verification was selected as the concentration in between the dilution factor that returned 5/5 positive test outcomes (100%) and the next dilution factor that returned 0/5 positive (0%) based on the qualitative result. Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Label: Limit of Quantiation (LOQ). The minimum amount or concentration of analyte in the test sample that can be quantified with acceptable precision. Concentration units must be specified in the "Units" column! For quantiative tests.
Notes: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Label: Signal to noise ratio used to define the limit of quantification in standard deviations.
Description of how limit of quantition was determined.
Notes:
COVID-19 Home Test was tested with up to a concentration
of 106.43 TCID 50 /mL of heat inactivated SARS-CoV-2 virus
(USA-WA1/2020 Isolate). Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Label: Description of high dose hook effect.
Notes: Example: No high dose hook effect was observed when the Ellume COVID-19 Home Test was tested with up to a concentration of 106.43 TCID 50 /mL of heat inactivated SARS-CoV-2 virus (USA-WA1/2020 Isolate). Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Label: The proportion of system-based positives; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FN). Used for comparison with a VQA standard.
The proportion of system-based negatives; calculated as 100xTN/(TN+FP). Used for comparison with a VQA standard.
ROC-based performance. AUC under ROC curve.
List of false positive rate values (1-specificity)
List of true positive rate values (sensitivity)
Analytical sensitivity is defined as the slope of the calibration curve.
Notes: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Pe3k3fJNe8

Label: Unit of analytical sensitivity
Impact of variants/mutations on test results. Specificity with respect to variants/mutations compared to wildtype
Notes: Analysis can be in silico and wet testing

Label: Name of organism tested for cross-reactivity against target organism
Concentration of cross-reacting organism.
Concentation unit used for cross-reacting organism.
Result of cross-reactivity test against target organism. A positive results indicates that cross-reacting organism gives a positive signal.
Description of observed cross-reactivity.
Name of the interfering substance.
Name of the entity that provided the interfering substance.
Concentration of the interfering substance.
Concentration unit  used for interfering substance.
Description of observed interference.
Notes:
Example:  There was no interference of SARS-CoV-2 detection
observed from any of the substances tested except for
bleach which was shown to interfere at the initial
concentration of 1% v/v tested. Further testing indicated that
the highest bleach level the test system could tolerate was
0.2% v/v. Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Label: Positive Percent Agreement (PPA). The proportion of non-reference standard positive subjects in whom the new test is positive.
Negative Percent Agreement (NPA). The proportion of non-reference standard negative subjects in whom the new test is negative.

Percentage of total subjects where the
new test and the non-reference standard agree.

A particular disease, a disease stage, health status, or any other identifiable condition within a patient, such as staging a disease already known to be present, or a health condition that should prompt clinical action, such as the initiation, modification, or termination of treatment.

The best available method for establishing the presence or absence of the target condition; the reference standard can be a single test or method, or a combination of methods and techniques, including clinical follow-up.
The subjects/patients (and specimen types) included in the study

Stratification of subjects, e.g., days since onset of symptoms, asymptomatic vs. symptomatic, co-infections, PCR Cycle Threshold, n x LOD concentration ranges for contrived samples, number of subjects in each category in a separate data elements.
True Positives (TP). The number of subjects/specimens with true positive test results
False Positives (FP). The number of subjects/specimens with false positive test results
True Negatives (TN). The number of subjects/specimens with true negative test results.
False Negatives (FN). The number of subjects/specimens with false negative test results
The proportion of subjects with the target condition in whom the test is positive; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FN). Used for comparison with a reference (Gold) standard.
Notes: PCR is Gold standard for COVID-19. For comparison with a non-reference standard use percent agreement metrics.

Label: Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval.
Lower bound of confidence interval.
Upper bound of confidence interval.
The proportion of subjects without the target condition in whom the test is negative; calculated as 100xTN/(FP+TN).
Notes: PCR is Gold standard for COVID-19. For comparison with a non-reference standard use percent agreement metrics.

Label: The proportion of test positive patients who have the target condition; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FP)
The proportion of test negative patients who do not have the target condition; calculated as 100xTN/(TN+FN)

Tissue Culture Infectious Dose 50% (TCID50) endpoint is the 50% infectious endpoint in cell culture. The TCID50 is the dilution of virus that under the conditions of the assay can be expected to infect 50% of the culture vessels inoculated. (TCID50/ml)
Cell line used for producing virus
